soc.communication

Class NetConnection

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.communication.Connection
      • soc.communication.NetConnection
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Runnable

    public final class NetConnection
extends Connection
implements java.lang.Runnable, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    A TCP client's connection at a server. Reads from the net, writes atomically to the net and holds the connection data

    This class has a run method, but you must start the thread yourself. Constructors will not create or start a thread.

    As used within JSettlers, the structure of this class has much in common with MemConnection, as they both subclass Connection. If you add something to one class you should probably add it to the other, or to the superclass instead.

    Refactored in v2.0.0 to extend Connection instead of Thread.

    Before JSettlers v2.0.00, this class was called Connection.

    Author:
    Cristian Bogdan
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getHost

        public java.lang.String getHost()
        Specified by:
        getHost in class Connection
        Returns:
        Hostname of the remote end of the connection

      • connect

        public boolean connect(boolean debugTraffic)
        Set up the connection to read from the network; called only by the server. If successful, also sets connectTime to now. Before calling connect(), be sure to make a new Thread(this) and start() it for the inbound reading thread.

        Connection must be unnamed (Connection.getData() == null) at this point.

        Specified by:
        connect in class Connection
        Returns:
        true if thread start was successful, false if an error occurred.

      • setAccepted

        public void setAccepted()
                 throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Description copied from class: Connection
        Intended for server or server proxy to call: Set our accepted flag. Peer must be non-null to set accepted. If our EOF is set, will not set accepted, but will not throw exception. (This happens if the server socket closes while we're in its accept queue.)
        Specified by:
        setAccepted in class Connection
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If we can't be, or already are, accepted

      • isInputAvailable

        public boolean isInputAvailable()
        Is input available now, without blocking? Same idea as FilterInputStream.available().
        Specified by:
        isInputAvailable in class Connection
        Since:
        1.0.5

      • run

        public void run()
        Inbound reading thread: continuously read from the net.

        When starting the thread, Connection.getData() must be null; connect(boolean) mentions and checks that, but connect() is a different thread.

        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • send

        public final void send(SOCMessage socMessage)
        Send this message over a network socket connection.

        Because the connection protocol uses DataOutputStream.writeUTF(String), str must be no longer than 65535 bytes when encoded into UTF-8 (which is not Java's internal string encoding): See Connection.MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE_UTF8.

        Threads: Safe to call from any thread.

        Specified by:
        send in class Connection
        Parameters:
        socMessage - Data to send

      • disconnect

        public void disconnect()
        close the socket, stop the reader; called after conn is removed from server structures
        Specified by:
        disconnect in class Connection

      • disconnectSoft

        public void disconnectSoft()
        Accept no further input, allow output to drain, don't immediately close the socket. Once called, isConnected() will return false, even if output is still being sent to the other side.
        Specified by:
        disconnectSoft in class Connection
        Since:
        1.0.3
